Article.ArticleTitle: Increased tropospheric ozone levels as a public health issue during COVID-19 lockdown and estimation the related pulmonary diseases.

AbstractText: The aims of this study were to i) investigate the variation of tropospheric ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) levels during the COVID-19 lockdown; ii) determine the relationships between O<sub>3</sub> concentrations with the number of COVID-19 cases; and iii) estimate the O<sub>3</sub>-related health effects in Southwestern Iran (Khorramabad) over the time period 2019-2021. The hourly O<sub>3</sub> data were collected from ground monitoring stations, as well as retrieved from Sentinel-5 satellite data for showing the changes in O<sub>3</sub> levels pre, during, and after lockdown period. The concentration-response function model was applied using relative risk (RR) values and baseline incidence (BI) to assess the O<sub>3</sub>-related health effects. Compared to 2019, the annual O<sub>3</sub> mean concentrations increased by 12.2% in 2020 and declined by 3.9% in 2021. The spatiotemporal changes showed a significant O<sub>3</sub> increase during COVID-19 lockdown, and a negative correlation between O<sub>3</sub> levels and the number of COVID-19 cases was found (r = - 0.59, p < 0.05). In 2020, the number of hospital admissions for cardiovascular diseases increased by 4.0 per 10<sup>5</sup> cases, the mortality for respiratory diseases increased by 0.7 per 10<sup>5</sup> cases, and the long-term mortality for respiratory diseases increased by 0.9 per 10<sup>5</sup> cases. Policy decisions are now required to reduce the surface O<sub>3</sub> concentrations and O<sub>3</sub>-related health effects in Iran.
